p: Chloroplasts are important sites for plant photosynthesis, which converts light energy into chemical energy (through electron transfer reactions), and supplies NADPH and ATP for CO 2 fixation into carbohydrates and for the synthesis of several essential compounds of plant growth 46- 49. In photosynthetic electron transfer reactions, electrons are generated by splitting water by light energy, and are transferred via photosystem II (PSII), cytochrome (Cyt) b 6f complex and photosystem I (PSI) to ferredoxin (Fd). Fd is the first soluble electron acceptor of the electron transport chain, and determines the efficiency of the electron transfer between the thylakoid membrane and the soluble enzymes dependent on these electrons 50. In this study, we found that miR156 targets Fd (Table S8 and Table S9) were expressed up-regulated in fruit, and the photosynthesis in fruit can be improved by increasing the efficiency of the electron transfer, which is similar to the results of reducing levels of miR156 promoting the rate of photosynthesis in plant leaves 51- 54. Ferredoxin-NADP + oxidoreductase (FNR) is the key enzyme linking the light reactions of photosynthesis to carbon assimilation, which functions in the last step of the linear electron transfer (LET), mediating electron flow from reduced Fd to NADPH for fixation of CO 2 in the Calvin cycle 46, 47, 50.
